articles.headline: Providing a Pandemic Safety Net, Nonprofits Need Their Own
articles.snippet: Even as the economic crisis creates new demand for their services, organizations with millions of workers are resorting to layoffs as revenues dry up.
articles.abstract: Even as the economic crisis creates new demand for their services, organizations with millions of workers are resorting to layoffs as revenues dry up.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the grip of the coronavirus pandemic, the Y.M.C.A. has provided a lifeline to many vulnerable Americans. As the health crisis and its economic disruption eat away at the group’s revenues, the question is whether anyone will throw a lifeline to the rescuers.

articles.headline: Inside Trump’s About-Face on the Republican Convention in Jacksonville
articles.snippet: Faced with a surging pandemic, resistance from local officials in Florida and deadlines for items like hotel payments, Mr. Trump chose to cancel the convention in an effort to cast himself as putting safety first.
articles.abstract: Faced with a surging pandemic, resistance from local officials in Florida and deadlines for items like hotel payments, Mr. Trump chose to cancel the convention in an effort to cast himself as putting safety first.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni, Alexander Burns and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: Anatomy of an Election ‘Meltdown’ in Georgia
articles.snippet: New voting machines and the pandemic exacerbated distrust of the state’s oversight of elections and voter access. What does this mean for November?
articles.abstract: New voting machines and the pandemic exacerbated distrust of the state’s oversight of elections and voter access. What does this mean for November?
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, Daryl Marvin got his first taste of voting in Georgia.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim, Reid J. Epstein and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: The Great Au Pair Rush
articles.snippet: When the Trump administration shut the borders to many new au pairs, those already in the country found they had something new: options.
articles.abstract: When the Trump administration shut the borders to many new au pairs, those already in the country found they had something new: options.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the au pair decided to change families, she feared she was taking a major risk.

articles.headline: Corporate Insiders Pocket $1 Billion in Rush for Coronavirus Vaccine
articles.snippet: Well-timed stock bets have generated big profits for senior executives and board members at companies developing vaccines and treatments.
articles.abstract: Well-timed stock bets have generated big profits for senior executives and board members at companies developing vaccines and treatments.
articles.lead_paragraph: On June 26, a small South San Francisco company called Vaxart made a surprise announcement: A coronavirus vaccine it was working on had been selected by the U.S. government to be part of Operation Warp Speed, the flagship federal initiative to quickly develop drugs to combat Covid-19.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: Officials Push U.S.-China Relations Toward Point of No Return
articles.snippet: Top aides to President Trump want to leave a lasting legacy of ruptured ties between the two powers. China’s aggression has been helping their cause.
articles.abstract: Top aides to President Trump want to leave a lasting legacy of ruptured ties between the two powers. China’s aggression has been helping their cause.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Step by step, blow by blow, the United States and China are dismantling decades of political, economic and social engagement, setting the stage for a new era of confrontation shaped by the views of the most hawkish voices on both sides.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Don’t Ban TikTok. Make an Example of It.
articles.snippet: There is plenty the U.S. government could do to ensure that TikTok acts responsibly without getting rid of it altogether.
articles.abstract: There is plenty the U.S. government could do to ensure that TikTok acts responsibly without getting rid of it altogether.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a while, it seemed that TikTok might dodge the techlash. After all, what could be problematic about a short-form video app featuring a bunch of teenagers and 20-somethings doing choreographed dances, roller skating, hanging out in influencer mansions and cutting into photorealistic cakes?

articles.headline: ‘You Do the Right Things, and Still You Get It’
articles.snippet: A Texas family tried to ward off the virus. But as cases in the state soared and debates about masks and distancing raged, there was only so much they could control.
articles.abstract: A Texas family tried to ward off the virus. But as cases in the state soared and debates about masks and distancing raged, there was only so much they could control.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Elaine Roberts, a longtime bagger at a supermarket, tried to be so careful. She put on gloves and stopped riding the bus to work, instead relying on her father to drive her to keep their family safe. She wore masks — in space-themed fabrics stitched by her sister — as she stacked products on shelves, helped people to their cars and retrieved carts from the parking lot.

articles.headline: Upsides for Some Remote Workers; Lost Pay and Security for Others
articles.snippet: Working from home creates economic winners and losers. It can benefit highly skilled employees but depress others’ wages and make it hard to organize.
articles.abstract: Working from home creates economic winners and losers. It can benefit highly skilled employees but depress others’ wages and make it hard to organize.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the pandemic hit and tens of millions of American workers suddenly redeployed to their basements and living rooms, it was easy to imagine that their workdays would unfold roughly as before, with communication tools like Slack and Zoom substituting for face-to-face interactions (and maybe with slightly greater multitasking opportunities).

articles.headline: A Liberal Town Built Around Confederate Generals Rethinks Its Identity
articles.snippet: In Lexington, Va., where Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson are buried, people are reassessing the town’s ties to a legacy that symbolizes slavery and oppression.
articles.abstract: In Lexington, Va., where Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson are buried, people are reassessing the town’s ties to a legacy that symbolizes slavery and oppression.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Va. — It’s a short drive in Lexington from a home on Confederate Circle past the Stonewall Jackson Memorial Cemetery and over to the Robert E. Lee Hotel, where locals like to stop for a drink.

articles.headline: Did Hearst’s Culture Kill Hearst’s Biggest Magazine Story?
articles.snippet: The workplace environment at the company’s magazine division was troubled under Troy Young. And it may not have been good for ambitious investigative journalism, either.
articles.abstract: The workplace environment at the company’s magazine division was troubled under Troy Young. And it may not have been good for ambitious investigative journalism, either.
articles.lead_paragraph: One evening in August 2018, Maximillian Potter, then a writer for Esquire magazine, was sitting in a restaurant in California’s inland empire, trying to persuade a man in his 30s to share his memories of rape and abuse at the hands of powerful men in Hollywood in the late 1990s.

articles.headline: Cities in Bind as Turmoil Spreads Far Beyond Portland
articles.snippet: Galvanized in part by the deployment of federal agents in Portland, Ore., protesters have returned to the streets in Oakland, Seattle and elsewhere.
articles.abstract: Galvanized in part by the deployment of federal agents in Portland, Ore., protesters have returned to the streets in Oakland, Seattle and elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — A series of strident new protests over police misconduct rattled cities across the country over the weekend, creating a new dilemma for state and local leaders who had succeeded in easing some of the turbulence in their streets until a showdown over the use of federal agents in Oregon stirred fresh outrage.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker, Thomas Fuller and Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: They Crossed Oceans to Lift Their Families Out of Poverty. Now, They Need Help.
articles.snippet: As the pandemic destroys paychecks, migrant workers are sending less money home, threatening an increase in poverty from South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa to Eastern Europe and Latin America.
articles.abstract: As the pandemic destroys paychecks, migrant workers are sending less money home, threatening an increase in poverty from South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa to Eastern Europe and Latin America.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — For more than a decade, Flavius Tudor has shared the money he has made in England with his mother in Romania, regularly sending home cash that enabled her to buy medicine.

articles.headline: Hoping to Understand the Virus, Everyone Is Parsing a Mountain of Data
articles.snippet: The coronavirus pandemic has left ordinary people debating case counts, positivity rates and hospitalization numbers in hopes of understanding the virus’s path.
articles.abstract: The coronavirus pandemic has left ordinary people debating case counts, positivity rates and hospitalization numbers in hopes of understanding the virus’s path.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The latest count of new coronavirus cases was jarring: Some 1,500 virus cases were identified three consecutive days last week in Illinois, and fears of a resurgence in the state even led the mayor of Chicago to shut down bars all over town on Friday.

articles.headline: Jeff Bezos Cast in a Role He Never Wanted: Amazon’s D.C. Defender
articles.snippet: The chief executive, who testifies before Congress for the first time on Wednesday, had taken a hands-off approach with lawmakers in Washington.
articles.abstract: The chief executive, who testifies before Congress for the first time on Wednesday, had taken a hands-off approach with lawmakers in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last September, Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, rattled off terrifying statistics about the warming planet from the storied National Press Club, two blocks from the White House. Then he said he had something exciting to announce.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Karen Weise

articles.headline: We’ll Be Wearing Masks for a While. Why Not Make Them Nice?
articles.snippet: Motorized air purifiers and heated sanitizers. Breathable fabrics and chic prints. With face coverings here to stay, consumers are starting to demand more than cheap throwaways.
articles.abstract: Motorized air purifiers and heated sanitizers. Breathable fabrics and chic prints. With face coverings here to stay, consumers are starting to demand more than cheap throwaways.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Rieko Kawanishi is the first to admit that the pearl-laden mask she designed is not the most effective defense against the coronavirus. “It’s full of holes,” she said with a laugh.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
